title: 112_s3412
content: The Act is titled the "Middle Class Tax Cut Act" and includes temporary extensions of tax relief measures from 2001, 2003, and 2010. It also extends the election to expense certain depreciable business assets and provides alternative minimum tax relief. The Act, titled the "Middle Class Tax Cut Act," includes temporary extensions of tax relief measures from 2001, 2003, and 2010. It provides alternative minimum tax relief and budgetary effects. The "Middle Class Tax Cut Act" includes temporary extensions of tax relief measures from 2001, 2003, and 2010, amending income tax rates for high-income taxpayers. The "Middle Class Tax Cut Act" includes amendments to income tax rates for high-income taxpayers, with a new 33-percent rate bracket for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012. The "Middle Class Tax Cut Act" introduces a new 36 percent tax rate for high-income taxpayers, applicable to taxable income exceeding a certain threshold. The term "applicable amount" is defined as the difference between the applicable threshold and the sum of certain amounts for the taxable year. The "Middle Class Tax Cut Act" establishes a 36 percent tax rate for high-income taxpayers with taxable income above specific thresholds. The term "applicable threshold" varies based on subsections, ranging from $250,000 to $200,000. The "Middle Class Tax Cut Act" sets a 36 percent tax rate for high-income taxpayers with taxable income above certain thresholds. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012, subject to the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. SEC. 102. TEMPORARY EXTENSION OF 2003 TAX RELIEF. The Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003 is amended to extend the deadline to December 31, 2013. Additionally, a 20-percent capital gains rate is introduced for certain high-income individuals. The tax law amendment extends the deadline to December 31, 2013 and introduces a 20% capital gains rate for high-income individuals. The amendment specifies calculations for taxable income exceeding certain thresholds. The tax law amendment introduces a 15% and 20% capital gains rate for high-income individuals based on adjusted net capital gain. The tax law amendment increases the capital gains rate for high-income individuals from 15% to 20% and makes corresponding amendments to various sections. The tax law amendments increase the capital gains rate for high-income individuals to 20% for taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. Withholding amendments apply to payments made on or after January 1, 2013. These changes are subject to the Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003. SEC. 103. TEMPORARY EXTENSION OF 2010 TAX RELIEF. SEC. 103. TEMPORARY EXTENSION OF 2010 TAX RELIEF. Amendments are made to various tax credits for the years 2012 and 2013, including the American Opportunity Tax Credit, Child Tax Credit, and Earned Income Tax Credit. The amendment extends the rule disregarding refunds in federal programs until December 31, 2013. The effective dates for the amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. SEC. 104. TEMPORARY EXTENSION OF ELECTION TO EXPENSE CERTAIN DEPRECIABLE BUSINESS ASSETS. Section 179(b)(1) is amended to increase the dollar limitation to $250,000 for taxable years beginning in 2013. Section 179(b)(2) is also amended to adjust the reduction in limitation. The dollar limitation for taxable years beginning in 2013 is increased to $800,000. Amendments are made to various sections to update the year from 2013 to 2014. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. SEC. 201 amends section 55(d) to increase the alternative minimum tax exemption amounts for taxable years starting in 2012. SEC. 202 extends alternative minimum tax relief for nonrefundable personal credits. The amendments made in section 26(a) apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. The budgetary effects of the Act will not be included in the PAYGO scorecards. S. 3412 is an act to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for tax relief for middle-class families in the 112th Congress, 2nd Session.
